docs.abstract: This year's World Series showcases not only baseball's finest teams, but also the regrettable fashion trend of the baggy, pajama-pant look worn by players across the leagues.

docs.snippet: For two American chaplains at Nuremberg prison in Germany, the climactic end of the initial phase of postwar judgment coincided with Game 7 of the 1946 World Series....
docs.lead_paragraph: For two American chaplains at Nuremberg prison in Germany, the climactic end of the initial phase of postwar judgment coincided with Game 7 of the 1946 World Series.
docs.abstract: Dan Barry This Land column notes that for Revs Henry Gerecke and Sixtus O'Connor, two American chaplains at Nuremberg prison in Germany, climactic end of the initial phase of postwar judgment coincided with Game 7 of 1946 World Series between Boston Red Sox and St Louis Cardinals.

headline.main: A World Away, the Seventh Game; Close at Hand, Condemned Nazis
headline.print_headline: A World Away, the Seventh Game; Close at Hand, Condemned Nazis

docs.snippet: BUCKNER--John Crawford, PhD. (age 55) of Weston, MA and Marstons Mills, MA, died unexpectedly of natural causes on September 29, 2013. Born in Boston, on October 3, 1957, Dr. Buckner was raised in Seattle, where he graduated from the Lakeside Scho...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUCKNER--John Crawford, PhD. (age 55) of Weston, MA and Marstons Mills, MA, died unexpectedly of natural causes on September 29, 2013. Born in Boston, on October 3, 1957, Dr. Buckner was raised in Seattle, where he graduated from the Lakeside School. He went onto Stanford University, graduating with honors and distinction in Psychology. He subsequently received a PhD in Psychology from the University of Maryland followed by a research career in psychiatric epidemiology and prevention at the National Institutes of Mental Health, the National Center on Family Homelessness, and finally at the Harvard Children's Hospital Boston. Dr. Buckner published widely and lectured on the topics of community cohesion, the effects of homelessness and poverty on children, and on the concept of self-regulation in children. He took his work beyond his academic role by founding and running the non-profit organization, Community Resources Information, Inc., that operates the widely used website: www.massresources.org. The website provides information on resources that address basic needs of individuals and families. Outside his career, John was known as a superb athlete excelling in baseball in high school and college. He had become an outstanding golfer and was proud of winning the Willowbend Senior Club Championship in 2013. He climbed Mt. Kilimanjaro twice in his life, most recently in 2012 with his daughter Mila followed by a memorable safari with both Mila and his daughter, Kimberly. He enjoyed following current events and financial investments, his dogs, traveling, golfing, Cape Cod and keeping up with close friends. He was known for his generosity and kindness, his intellectual capacity, gentle manner and staying power. Above all, John was a loving and devoted family man who will be dearly missed. He is survived by his beloved wife, Dr. Elizabeth Cousins Buckner, his daughters Kimberly of New York and Mila of San Francisco, a brother, Dr. Frederick S. Buckner of Seattle, a sister, Catherine B. Hobbs of Corte Madera, CA, his mother, Ann S. Buckner of Seattle, and his father, Philip F. Buckner of Seattle and New York.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKNER, JOHN CRAWFORD

docs.snippet: Investing can require a leap of optimism, especially if you’re buying shares in a football player’s future earnings....
docs.lead_paragraph: Investing can require a leap of optimism, especially if you’re buying shares in a football player’s future earnings.
docs.abstract: Editorial observes that Fantex, young San Francisco-based company, has announced that it is offering to sell shares linked to the income that Houston Texans running back Arian Foster earns from his contract and sponsorships; contends that buying a share in the promise of Foster is similar to buying a share of Twitter, as both are unproven investments that appeal to people's innate optimism about the future.

docs.snippet: Entering the 2013-14 season, the N.B.A.’s upper class — which, on its lower end, includes both New York teams — has grown to include about half the league....
docs.lead_paragraph: Entering the 2013-14 season, the N.B.A.’s upper class — which, on its lower end, includes both New York teams — has grown to include about half the league.
docs.abstract: Preview of 2013-14 NBA season assesses teams, from those who have plenty, to those who have little, some and none.
